RT @OversightDems Today, @RepPressley and Chairwoman @RepMaloney announced 2 bills - the STRONG Support for Children Act & the Children’s Protection Act - to take holistic and community-based approaches to addressing the growing crisis of childhood trauma. 

Read more here: https://oversight.house.gov/news/press-releases/pressley-and-maloney-to-introduce-bold-legislation-to-address-growing-childhood

Proud to continue the work of the late @OversightDems Chair Elijah Cummings in partnership with Chair @RepMaloney, who’s introducing the Children’s Protection Act to center the wellbeing of all children & require proposed federal rules to undergo a childhood trauma impact study.

This bill creates new grants to support local health departments working to address trauma & ensure that programming is accessible to all children & families regardless of immigration status, ability to pay, or prior involvement in the legal system. 

https://edit-pressley.house.gov/media/press-releases/pressley-and-maloney-introduce-bold-legislation-address-growing-childhood

Childhood trauma is a crisis affecting families & communities across our country. But too often, our response to this trauma fails to reach those most impacted or address the systemic failures that trigger it. 

I’m introducing the STRONG Support for Children Act to change that.

RT @LibraryPolicy Michigan libraries are working hard to provide innovative, high quality service to patrons across the state! Thank you @RepAndyLevin for advocating on behalf of these Michigan libraries and all library workers with your Library Stabilization Fund Act. https://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/2020/10/08/libraries-pandemic-programs-reopening-virtual-books-help-aid/3585372001/
Through these efforts, I have realized that there is bipartisan support across Congress for libraries, and it’s my goal to continue to build on this support. 22//

The updated Heroes Act also sets aside $12 billion to close the homework gap by providing funding for Wi-Fi hotspots and connected devices for students and library patrons and $3 billion for emergency home connectivity. 21/
The steady campaign to save our libraries is paying off. When House Democrats updated the Heroes Act in September, we increased funding for the IMLS to $135 million. 20/
We currently have 64 cosponsors in the House and 17 in the Senate, and the support keeps growing. We are continuing to push for this bill to be included in any upcoming stimulus package. 19/
These funds would keep nearly 370,000 library workers on the job, defray costs related to safe re-opening and support a range of library services to millions of patrons. 18/

The Library Stabilization Fund Act would establish a $2 billion fund delivered through IMLS to address financial losses and bolster library services, with priority for the hardest hit communities. 17/

Thanks to the support of the @ALALibrary and a robust grassroots campaign to save our libraries, Senator Reed and I introduced the Library Stabilization Fund Act. 16/

https://www.libraryjournal.com/?detailStory=library-stabilization-fund-act-seeks-2-billion-pandemic-losses-reopening-costs-more-covid-19
I reached out to my colleague, @SenJackReed of Rhode Island – a long-time champion of libraries – to discuss potential legislation. 15/

That’s when my team and I realized we needed to strengthen our advocacy for library funding by introducing a bill that would emphasize the $2 billion in IMLS funding we had been asking for while also outlining exactly how the money should be dispersed. 14/

While the Heroes Act included important provisions for libraries – as well as comprehensive public health and economic resources for the American people – it was clear from conversations I was having with librarians and library advocates that libraries would need more help. 13/

And let me just take a moment to underscore that the group of members that got behind this effort was diverse in every sense of the word—demonstrating that this is a priority for communities across party lines and across this country. 12/

When House Democrats began drafting our next piece of the Heroes Act, I sent a letter to Congressional leaders with Rep. Raul Grijalva of Arizona, a former co-chair of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, and Rep. Don Young, a Republican from Alaska. 11/
https://andylevin.house.gov/media/press-releases/levin-grijalva-and-young-lead-bipartisan-letter-urging-support-america-s

Our efforts – along with pressure from library advocacy groups across the country – helped secure $50,000,000 in CARES Act funding for the IMLS. 10/

https://andylevin.house.gov/media/press-releases/rep-andy-levin-35-bipartisan-house-members-call-increased-library-funding
I led a letter to Congressional leadership ahead of the negotiations for the CARES Act, requesting funding for library services within the Institute of Museum and Library Services, or IMLS. 9/

As the president offered a decentralized, uncoordinated response, I argued the correct strategy was to bolster our public health infrastructure and defend public institutions that already had the know-how to tackle this crisis—like libraries. 8/

When stay-at-home orders were first being put in place, lawmakers needed to respond quickly to provide communities with public health and economic resources. I knew that strengthening libraries would be one of the best ways to do this. 7/
Libraries are innovators that are working towards a truly noble goal: to provide critical services to every person in the community at no cost. 6/

Libraries provide hotspot lending for families who can’t access WiFi. They connect us to telehealth services; provide online homework assistance to students; and put on workforce development workshops to help unemployed Americans find jobs. 5/
I could talk about the benefit of library books all day, but I think it’s important to understand that libraries are more than just book repositories for their communities. 4/

My wife Mary & I raised our four children on many reasonable limitations – but one exception was how many books they could take out at the library. Five books? Ten books? Fine! We won’t protest. Libraries have been absolutely central to creating a reading culture in our home. 3/
I have been a strong supporter of libraries since childhood, and libraries have played a vital role in my children’s education.  2/

I believe there is still a right and wrong. This plot is wrong. 

And it’s incumbent on all of us to stand up to oppose this behavior, and these growing threats.

Leadership climate is set at the top –– starting with the Oval Office –– and leaders have a moral responsibility to set the example for how we disagree without enabling hate and violence.

Not just when something like today’s events happen, but every day.

They have purposely stoked it in a misguided attempt to appease their alleged base.

These same leaders should not now feign surprise that some extremists have turned such rhetoric into action.

And, importantly, it shows that extreme rhetoric and stoking tensions have a very specific cost.

Elected leaders in Michigan and Washington alike have encouraged and tolerated threats of violence and hate against those with whom they disagree.
Today’s arrests confirm again that they are right, and should be a wake-up call to anyone who uses the same violent incitement as the accused, or refuses to speak out against it.

Both here in the state and on the Homeland Security Committee, our law enforcement and intelligence agencies have been warning us with increasing urgency about the threat of violent domestic extremism.

If true, they are cowards and criminals and should be treated accordingly.

Make no mistake: This is about as far from their proclaimed patriotism as one can get. This is terrorism.

I am deeply disturbed to hear of the plot, conducted in part in my own district, to kidnap our Governor.

I’m so thankful to federal, state and local law enforcement for taking the threat seriously and getting to the perpetrators before they could act.

I’ve always said that the internet needs to be open, chaotic, and democratic—and accessible to all. As our society evolves, so too must our protections for people with disabilities.
The CVAA also expanded access to closed captioning and audio descriptions for video, including for matters of life-saving emergency information.

I authored the CVAA to ensure that no one is left behind when it comes to emerging technologies. My law requires that smartphones, tablets, and set-top boxes are designed with accessibility features at launch, not added after the fact.

10 years ago today, President Obama signed into law my 21st Century Communications and Video Accessibility Act into law. This landmark accessibility legislation forever changed the digital landscape to be more accessible for people who have disabilities.

7/ But Wisconsin HAD provided proof. It just wasn't ENOUGH for Barrett, who clearly had read plenty of NRA-funded studies arguing against background checks.

So, Barrett thinks that gun laws are unconstitutional so long as a study exists that says more guns equal less crime.

6/ Second, she said that legislatures had to "prove" that the gun law they passed would reduce violence, and claimed Wisconsin hadn't provided that proof. Thus, Barrett said the restriction was unconstitutional.

5/ In Kanter, Barrett said two things that made clear she intends to legislate from the bench.

First, she said that courts, not the legislature, should decide who is too dangerous to own a gun. She said courts should take that power away from the legislature. Just mind-blowing.

4/ But it's not just her general philosophy - it's her stunning dissent in Kanter v. Barr. There, she broke with decades of precedent (and Scalia's decision in DC v. Heller) upholding the constitutionality of background checks, and argued that felons have a right to own guns.

3/ So, for instance, that makes it easy for her to rule against bans on weapons that didn't exist in the 1700s (like semi-automatic weapons), or restrictions on guns in places that didn't exist (like airplanes), or background checks for felonies that post-date 1787.

2/ Like Gorsuch/Kavanaugh/Alito/Thomas, she is an "orginalist" on guns. It's total BS - just a way to legislate from the court and invalidate modern gun laws. 

But basically, she believes that if the regulation didn't exist in 1787 then it's unconstitutional.
